fullProgramDescription: The Computer Science major at UC Berkeley is designed to provide students with a broad foundation in the fundamental concepts and techniques of computer science, as well as the opportunity to specialize in one or more areas. The program includes coursework in algorithms, computer architecture, operating systems, programming languages, and software engineering, among other topics. Students also complete a set of core requirements in mathematics and science.
shortProgramDescription: UC Berkeley's CS B.S. provides a rigorous foundation in computer science, preparing students for careers or graduate study.
classHighlights: The major requires foundational courses in programming, including CS 61A (Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs), CS 61B (Data Structures), and CS 61C (Computer Architecture).

Students complete a set of core courses in computer science, including CS 70 (Discrete Mathematics and Probability Theory), CS 162 (Operating Systems and System Programming), and CS 170 (Efficient Algorithms and Intractable Problems).
Mathematics and science requirements include Calculus (Math 1A-1B or Math 16A-16B), Discrete Mathematics (CS 70), and a science elective.
Students choose from a range of upper-division electives, including courses in artificial intelligence, computer networks, database systems, and software engineering.
The major also requires a set of technical electives, allowing students to specialize in one or more areas of computer science.
learningOutcomes: Apply mathematical and computational principles to solve problems in computer science.
Design and implement software systems, including algorithms and data structures.
Understand computer systems, architecture, and organization.
Analyze and evaluate the complexity of algorithms.
Communicate technical concepts in written and oral form.
Work effectively in teams to design and implement software systems.
additionalInformation: Students must complete a set of breadth requirements in addition to major requirements. Upper-division courses must be taken for a letter grade. Students are encouraged to participate in research and internships to gain practical experience.
